DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS:
content:
ASIA-PAC

US is said to plan the next China tariffs if talks between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi fail, with an additional USD 257bln of trade targeted on the new US list according to sources. However, there were later unconfirmed Twitter reports that the White House was unaware of any new developments related to tariffs on China. (Newswires)

Chinese regulators are said to propose a 50% cut to car purchase tax. (Newswires)

UK

UK Chancellor Hammond delivered the budget today in which he stated that the era of austerity is finally coming to an end and that the UK will harvest a 'double deal dividend' if EU talks are positive, while he announced that VAT threshold for businesses will remain unchanged for an additional two years and that they will introduce a UK digital services tax on large tech giants which will raise GBP 400mln/year when adopted in April 2020.

UK Chancellor Hammond said the higher rate threshold for income tax will increase to GBP 50,000 and that tax-free allowance for income will increase to GBP 12,500 in April 2020. UK Chancellor Hammond said will increase remote gaming duty on games of chance by 21%; will freeze short-haul air passenger duty and increase other air passenger duty in line with inflation.
Furthermore, Hammond said we are confident that a Brexit deal can be secured but are not complacent and are increasing the Brexit contingency funds for departments to GBP 2bln, while he also noted that they will conduct a full spending review next year and that the national living wage will rise by 4.9% in April 2019.

OBR sees 2019 UK GDP growth at 1.6% (vs. prev. 1.3%), 2020 1.4% (vs. prev. 1.3%), 2021 1.4% (vs. prev. 1.4%), 2023 1.6%.
OBR sees sustained real wage growth in each of the next 5 years; 2018/19 budget deficit 1.2% of GDP (March 1.8%), 2019/20 budget deficit of less than 1.4% of GDP (March 1.6%)

UK DMO cut 2018/2019 gilt issuance remit by GBP 8.5bln to GBP 97.5bln vs Exp. GBP 101.0bln (Prev. GBP 106bln).
Furthermore, it plans to reduce net treasury bill sales by GBP 4bln in 2018/2019 vs. Exp. no change, while projection shows 2019/20 gross financing requirement of GBP 132.7bln (March projection GBP 147.4bln). (Newswires).


EU

German Chancellor Merkel confirmed she is not seeking any re-election as CDU head or CDU lawmaker and not seeking any political posts after current terms ends in 2021. Furthermore, Merkel said this is her last term as chancellor and that she will not run for chancellor if a snap election was held before 2021. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Russian Deputy PM Kozak said the Russian government does not rule out imposing prohibitive export duty on crude and oil products. (RIA)
 

US

US President Trump attorney Giuliani said Trump might answer questions from Special Counsel Mueller after the mid-term elections, if a broader deal can be reached. (Newswires)

US PCE Price Index YY Sep 2.0% (Prev. 2.2%). (Newswires)
US Core PCE Price Index YY Sep 2.0% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 2.0%)
US Personal Income MM Sep 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.3%, Rev. 0.4%)
US Personal Consumption Real MM Sep 0.3% (Prev. 0.2%, Rev. 0.4%)
 

MARKET RECAP

IBM’s (IBM) bid for Red Hat (RHT) today caused Red Hat to shoot up by nearly 50% at highs and IBM to fall, reaching lows of -5%. Auto makers were top movers after reports Chinese regulators are to propose a 50% car purchase tax cut, fuelling moves for General Motors (GM), Ford (F) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU). Cerner (CERN) traded higher on the back of an upgrade at Leerink. Shire (SHPG) made gains after reports that Takeda would divest certain treatments to gain EU approval of their merger. Boeing (BA) was a bottom mover in the wake of the Lion Air Flight crash. Video game developers Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) all moved lower today. Amazon (AMZN) moved lower through the day dragging down the wider tech sector. SPX -0.66% at 2641, NDX -2.02% at 6714, DJI -1.01% at 24440.

The Treasury complex ended Monday’s session pretty much unchanged, and only marginally lower, with risk-sentiment deteriorating heading into the close triggering buying action, after the US said to plan the next China tariffs if Trump and Xi talks fail. In earlier trade, the complex saw some selling action after German Chancellor Merkel confirmed she is not seeking any re-election as CDU head and will step down as Chancellor at the end of her term. Yields were higher by less than 1bps at settlement and 2s30s and 5s30s were wider by c.1bps. Elsewhere, the US Treasury expects to borrow USD 425bln in Q4. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 2+ ticks lower at 118-30+.

US MARKET WRAP - 29 October 2018: Equities slide again amid re-surfacing of US-China trade tensions

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries flat, dollar up, crude down.

* REAR-VIEW: US to plan next China tariffs if Trump and Xi Jinping talks fail, German Chancellor Merkel to step down in 2021; no surprises in UK budget; US PCE firms; China regulators mull 50% cut to car purchase tax, US planning next China tariffs.

* AHEAD: German State and National CPIs, EU GDP Flash Preliminary, ECB's Praet and Lautenschlager Speaking, Earnings include PFE, FB.

 

* TRADE: US said to plan the next China tariffs if Trump and Xi Jinping talks fail, additional USD 270bln of trade targeted on new US list, according to sources. Elsewhere, the US has temporarily blocked WTO dispute panels over metals tariffs. China is mulling a plan to cut auto taxes to offer support to the sector which has been battered by the trade conflict with the US.  

* UK BUDGET: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Hammond confirmed ‘austerity will end’ on the provison that the UK will secure an exit deal with the European Union. Most of the measures announced were leaked in advance, and there was little new of note. For market folks, the key news was gilt issuance in 2018/19 will be cut by GBP 8.5bln to 97.5bln; elsewhere, the OBR nudged up growth forecasts for 2019 and 2020. The Budget is contingent on progress with Brexit, and therefore, the possibility of an emergency budget before the Spring Budget remains a possibility. Also of note, the OBR revised its estimates of tax revenue forecasts. ING observed that there was a lack of detail on how the ‘ending austerity’ measures will be funded while sticking to fiscal discipline. “It is widely believed that the government will need to look at tax rises to help square the funding circle, and there were some subtle hints of this in today’s budget with the announcement of new taxes on tech firms,” ING writes, “but given the government’s thin majority in Parliament, there is limited appetite for substantial tax rises at this point.”

* GERMANY: German Chancellor Merkel, during a briefing on the Hesse election results, confirmed she is not seeking any re-election as CDU head or CDU lawmaker and she is not looking at any political posts after current terms ends in 2021. She stated this is her last term as Chancellor, clarifying she will not run for the position even if snap election were needed to be held before 2021. Commenting on the votes, she said the elections in Bavaria and Hesse should serve as a turning point for the coalition government, noting she is responsible for what has happened since the federal election last year. Meanwhile, sources reported German Health Minister Jens Spahn announced candidacy to succeed Merkel as CDU party leader and CDU Secretary General Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer candidacy for the CDU chair position.

* BREXIT: UK PM May's spokesperson reported commitments are funded irrespective of a Brexit deal, adding economic interventions would be considered if economic circumstances change; he stressed they are not pursuing a Norway model for a Brexit deal. This followed from UK Chancellor Hammond’s comments over the weekend where he noted the UK will require new tax and spending plans, as well as an extension of austerity policies in the event of a no deal Brexit, while he added BoE may also need to act by adjusting interest rates. Elsewhere, DUP spokesperson Sammy Wilson announced  the DUP will support the budget but could oppose the government in the future if the exit deal means Northern Ireland 'is separated from the rest of the UK'.

* ITALY: An Italy's government source said that if the funds allocated for the pension reform and citizens income in 2018 budget are not fully used, they will go towards reduction of the 2.4% deficit target. Additionally, given the recent market turmoil, Il Corriere reported Italian PM Conte has asked for bank aid options if the spread worsens; Economy Minister Tria echoed the PM request noting the government is exploring various options to support banks in case of need. Note the Five-Star was said to oppose the use of state funds to rescue banks but is open to use state-guaranteed schemes to support mergers in the banking sector. Elsewhere, ANSA reported the Italian Government is set to submit the revised budget law to Parliament by Tuesday or Wednesday.

* SPX -0.66% at 2641, NDX -2.02% at 6714, DJI -1.01% at 24440. SECTORS: Energy -1.86%, Materials -0.31%, Industrials -1.69%, Cons Discretionary -1.52%, Cons Staples +1.08%, Healthcare +0.18%, Financials +0.80%, Tech -1.80%, Telecoms -1.61%, Utilities +1.36%.

*STOCK SPECIFICS: IBM’s (IBM) bid for Red Hat (RHT) today caused Red Hat to shoot up by nearly 50% at highs and IBM to fall, reaching lows of -5%. Auto makers were top movers after reports Chinese regulators are to propose a 50% car purchase tax cut, fuelling moves for General Motors (GM), Ford (F) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU). Cerner (CERN) traded higher on the back of an upgrade at Leerink. Shire (SHPG) made gains after reports that Takeda would divest certain treatments to gain EU approval of their merger. Boeing (BA) was a bottom mover in the wake of the Lion Air Flight crash. Video game developers Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) all moved lower today. Amazon (AMZN) moved lower through the day dragging down the wider tech sector.

* WTI (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.55 LOWER AT USD 67.04/BBL, BRENT (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.77 LOWER AT USD 77.34/BBL. Crude was lower on Monday; Citi explained that “supply uncertainty is normally a bullish factor for oil prices, but it turns out that the uncertainty over the impact of pending US sanctions on Iranian crude oil inventories is less clear, as it complicates the decision making for OPEC oil ministers at the upcoming December 6 summit in Vienna,” with Citi acknowledging risks that it plays out in a bearish fashion, “with any wait-and-see approach by OPEC running the risk of a Q1 surplus off the seasonal drop in global oil demand.” Citi says that OPEC’s response to the impact of Iranian sanctions has been enough to create a modest supply/demand surplus, but that might change, possibly without warning, “but for now it looks as though it continues to weigh on market sentiment,” Citi says. Elsewhere on Monday, South Korea's foreign minister Kang has requested US secretary of state Pompeo for US exemptions from Iranian sanctions.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 2+ TICKS LOWER  AT 118-30+. The Treasury complex ended Monday’s session pretty much unchanged, and only marginally lower, with risk-sentiment deteriorating heading into the close triggering buying action, after the US said to plan the next China tariffs if Trump and Xi talks fail. In earlier trade, the complex saw some selling action after German Chancellor Merkel confirmed she is not seeking any re-election as CDU head and will step down as Chancellor at the end of her term. Yields were higher by less than 1bps at settlement and 2s30s and 5s30s were wider by c.1bps. Elsewhere, the US Treasury expects to borrow USD 425bln in Q4.

* USD: The Greenback has regained momentum after some consolidation and a pull-back to hold gains vs all G10 rivals bar the NZD, as the Kiwi holds close to the middle of a 0.6500-55 range amidst a broad improvement in risk sentiment after last week’s hefty global equity market declines. However, the DXY remains off best levels circa 96.70 and last Friday’s 96.860 peak with the ytd best at 96.984 still representing resistance ahead of 97.000 that could yet be tested given strong month end buying signals and the additional draw of SOMA and tax repatriation impulses.

* JPY, CHF: Extending their outperformance and declines vs the Dollar, with Usd/Jpy just below 112.50 while the Franc never really recovered from parity, though doing better vs the Eur as the cross remained below 1.1400.

* EUR, GBP: Both more contained vs the Usd after some volatile moves in early EU trade and ending with net losses as the single currency failed to reclaim 1.1400 and Cable drifted down a bit further towards 1.2800. There were upticks as the Chancellor began delivering his budget, though this was pared back and was more or less unchanged around 1.28 by the time the Chancellor was finishing up, as was expected. The Eur was undermined by more political dynamics as German Chancellor Merkel confirmed reports that she intends to stand down after her current term ends after another blow to the CDU-CSU ruling coalition via the Hesse regional election, while ongoing Brexit uncertainty and some pre-UK budget kept the Pound pressured, alongside the aforementioned October 31 Dollar bid.

* AUD, CAD: The Aud remained top-heavy ahead of 0.7100 vs its US counterpart throughout and perhaps wary of further CNH weakness towards 6.9700 even though the PBoC set the Usd/Cny lower overnight, while the Loonie never really recovered from 1.3100+ lows and retreated a bit further to around 1.3125 against the backdrop of soft crude prices.

* EM: The Lira gave up some of its gains seen after last week’s hawkish CBRT meeting (in word rather than deed), after Mexican President Elect Obrador said his government will build two new runways at a military base and upgrade the current airport, noting the decision will save the federal government around 100bln pesos. Usd/Try moved higher consolidating just above 5.5400. Elsewhere, the Real handed back initial upside through 3.6000 vs the Usd on Bolsonaro’s Brazilian election win and the Peso suffered additional losses over 19.8000 after Mexico scrapped its plans to build a new airport.

  • ON Semiconductor (ON) Q3 Adj. EPS USD 0.57 vs. Exp. USD 0.51, revenue USD 1.54bln vs. Exp. USD 1.51bln, Adj. gross margin 38.7%; sees Q4 revenue USD 1.48bln-1.53bln vs. Exp. USD 1.47bln, Q4 Adj. gross margin 37.1%-38.1%. (Newswires)
  • Yandex (YNDX) Q3 EPS USD 0.23 vs. Exp. USD 0.27, revenue USD 496.6mln vs. Exp. USD 470.6mln; sees FY18 results up 35%-38% vs. 2017. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech behemoth is expected to reveal new devices on Tuesday this week, where a new iPad Pro overhaul will be the focal point, other expected devices include a new laptop to replace the MacBook Air and a Mac mini. (Newswires)
  • Boeing (BA) – The aerospace co. said it was deeply saddened by the crash of the Lion Air Flight JT 610, a Boeing 737 Max 8 jet and stands ready to provide technical assistance to the accident investigation; the crash killed 189 people. (Newswires)
  • IBM (IBM), Red Hat (RHT) – IBM has acquired the open-source software co., Red Hat, for a cash deal valued at USD 190/shr or approximately USD 34bln; IBM expects accelerated growth in its financials within a year of closing. Jefferies noted that Red Hat is unlikely to see any other competing bids. (Newswires)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The pharma co. has had its cancer treatment, Zytiga, patent determined as invalid, this is a positive for other competitors such as Teva (TEVA), Mylan (MYL), and Amneal Pharmaceuticals (AMRX). (Newswires)
  • Pfizer (PFE) – The pharma co. has entered an agreement with the swiss Novartis (NVS SW) to investigate combinations for the treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The co.’s Sam's Club unit announced the opening of a new store in Dallas, Texas, which will be used to test new technology including electronic shelf labels that update prices automatically and 700 installed cameras, before it is implemented in other stores. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Auto names (GM, F, FCAU, TM) - Chinese regulators are said to propose a 50% cut to car purchase tax. (Newswires)
  • Baxter International (BAX) – The healthcare co. has received CE mark for its PrisMax system and its TherMax blood warmer. (Newswires)
  • Capital One Financial (COF), Discover Financial Services (DFS) – The banks have said they are becoming more cautious of consumer credit, not because they think borrowers will not be able to make repayments but because of a potential economic downturn. (WSJ)
  • Eli Lilly (LLY), Discerna (DRNA) – The two pharma co.s have entered a global licensing and research collaboration for new medicines to treat cardio-metabolic disease, neurodegeneration and pain. (Newswires)
  • Kroger (KR) – The co. affirms 2018 GAAP net earnings guidance of USD 3.88-4.03 per diluted share and Adj. net earnings USD 2.00-2.15 per diluted share. Expects capital investments (net of M&A) to be USD 3bln in 2018. Says remodelling work affects more than 1,000 stores creating a headwind in revenue for the rest of the year. Expects second half of the year results to be similar to the first half results. (Newswires)
  • Northrop Grumman (NOC) – The co. announces a USD 1bln accelerated stock repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • T-Mobile (TMUS), Sprint (S) – The two co.s are facing heightened probing efforts from the NY Attorney General ahead of their proposed USD 27bln merger, where it is concerned of monopolistic price hikes. (NY Post)
  • Barron’s writes that Yum China (YUMC) may be worth considering taking a position in as Chinese stocks look to be in a bear market, the co. has strong cash flow to make it resilient to the wider market downturn. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that Bank of America (BAC) is valued cheaply after the recent sell off of financials, as investors are too pessimistic about banks from the last crisis. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that the retailer At Home Group (HOME) could be a better pick over Amazon (AMZN), as it has been sold off recently, but the growth story still remains intact. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that more attention might need to be focused on chip makers, where recent fragile outlooks from Texas Instruments (TXN) and Western Digital (WDC) could indicate where the market is heading. (Barron’s)

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) – The companies could be facing billions in taxes in Asia and Latin America as governments seek to increase revenue from tech giants. (WSJ)
  • Qualcomm (QCOM), Apple (AAPL) – In a court hearing, the semiconductor co. Qualcomm has said that Apple is USD 7bln behind in royalty payments. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The electric automaker’s second largest shareholder, Baillie Gifford, said in The London Times that it would be willing to put more cash behind the co. and CEO Elon Musk if needed be, despite the ongoing SEC probe. Further on the SEC probe, Musk took to twitter to say that it was “total bs”. (London Times, Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Denbury Resources (DNR), Penn Virginia Corporation (PVAC) – Denbury Resources has acquired Penn Virginia for a cash and stock deal with a value of USD 1.7bln. (Newswires)
  • Shire (SHPG) – Takeda told European regulators that it could sell a treatment that Shire is developing due to overlapping with inflammatory bowel disease and Takeda’s Entyvio drug as it is looking to clear the merger. (Newswires)
  • TherapeuticsMD (TXMD) – The FDA approved Bijuv, an oral hormone therapy for the treatment of menopause symptoms, to be available in the US in Q2 2019. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 29th October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities are kicking off the week on the front-foot, despite the downbeat tone in Asia, Eurostoxx up 1.0%
  • EURUSD has been whippy between 1.1360-1.1415 trading parameters amidst reports that German Chancellor Merkel will not stand for re-election as CDU head after serving out the current term
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Core PCE and UK Chancellor Hammond to deliver the Autumn budget statement. Note: UK clocks moved back an hour on Sunday 28th October.

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mixed as the region’s attempts to pick itself up following last week’s stock rout, waned heading into this week’s key earnings releases and month-end. ASX 200 (+1.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) were both initially positive in which the healthcare sector led the broad upside in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark was less decisive as earnings dominated news flow. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.2%) were subdued with the mainland worst hit following softer Industrial Profit growth and a net liquidity drain by the PBoC, while this week’s key earnings including China’s big 4 banks further added to the tentativeness. Finally, 10yr JGBs were choppy as prices reflected the indecisiveness across stocks and eventually edged higher as the risk tone in Japan deteriorated.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 120bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9377 (Prev. 6.9510)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Sep) Y/Y 4.1% (Prev. 9.2%). (Newswires)

Chinese regulators are said to propose a 50% cut to car purchase tax. (Newswires)

UK

UK Chancellor Hammond said UK will require new tax and spending plans, as well as an extension of austerity policies in the event of a no deal Brexit, while he added BoE may also need to act by adjusting interest rates. (Sky News)

UK Health Minister Hancock says that he is confident we will get a good Brexit deal (Newswires)

EU's Moscovici says that a Brexit deal is the most likely outcome. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed United Kingdom at AA; Outlook Negative,

EU

German Chancellor Merkel wants to give up the leadership of the CDU but wants to remain as Germany's Chancellor. (DPA) German politician Friedrich Merz is said to be ready to run for the CDU head position. (Bild) German Chancellor Merkel has ruled out running for a Senior EU role, CDU sources say. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel’s governing coalition suffered heavy losses in the Hesse elections with the CDU (27.9% vs. Prev. 38.3%) and SPD (19.9% vs. Prev. 30.7%) each down around 10% compared to the previous election, while the Green party rose to 19.5% from 11.1% and AfD secured 12%. (BBC) German Chancellor Merkel says that she may not stand for re-election as head of the CPU party, according to the Spiegel editor. (Der Spiegel). Additionally, the DPA has said that German Chancellor Merkel wants to stay in her position. (DPA)

Italian PM Conte asked for bank aid options if spreads worsen. (Corriere)

S&P affirmed Italy at BBB; outlook cut to negative from stable and affirmed Germany at AAA; outlook stable. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed the Netherlands at AAA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Latvia at A-; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Norges bank state that on balance financial stability outlook is largely unchanged from a year ago. Adding that banks have become more resilient; the financial system is vulnerable to high household debt, high house prices and commercial property. Commenting that bank stress tests suggest a larger portion of the buffer requirement should vary over time. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are kicking off the week on the front-foot, despite the downbeat tone in Asia. As such, Eurostoxx 50 (+1.0%) is supported mostly by the financial sector following optimistic earnings from HSBC (+5.0%), which saw the likes of Intesa Sanpaolo (+3.7%), Deutsche Bank (+1.4%) and RBS (+3.0%) higher in tandem. Elsewhere, Europe’s auto stocks index (+3.7%) rose sharply following reports that Chinese regulators are said to propose a 50% cut to car purchase tax. Subsequently, DAX 30 outperforms as the index is buoyed by shares in Daimler (+4.6%), BMW (+4.3%) and Volkswagen (+5.7%). Finally, Euronext is experiencing problems in which the CAC and AEX remain halted until the technical glitches are resolved.

FX

USD - Nordea have highlighted three USD supportive factors heading into the month end: Month-end re-balancing, SOMA day & Tax reform prompting US firms to repatriate T-2 days before the end of the calendar month.

NZD/AUD/CAD - All performing well vs their US counterpart to varying degrees, with the Kiwi outpacing and bouncing firmly from overnight lows to 0.6555 vs circa 0.6500 amidst a broad upturn in risk sentiment, while Aud/Usd struggles around 0.7100 and the Loonie pivots 1.3100.

GBP/EUR - Both choppy, but the Pound relatively rangebound ahead of the UK budget and following mixed data, as Cable hovers above 1.2800 within a tight 1.2805-40 range. However, the single currency has been whippy between 1.1360-1.1415 trading parameters amidst reports that German Chancellor Merkel will not stand for re-election as CDU head after serving out the current term, but would like to remain as Chancellor in wake of another chastening regional result for the coalition. However, Eur/Usd has bounced firmly ahead of hefty option expiry interest at the 1.1350 strike (1.5 bn) and a sharp rally in EU auto stocks on China’s cut in purchase tax to 5% from 10%.

CHF/JPY - Victims of the improvement in risk appetite, with the Franc just off parity-plus lows and Jpy retreating from circa 111.80 to 112.25 amidst similar reversals in cross pairings.

SEK/NOK - Conversely, the Scandi crowns are registering decent gains vs the Eur amidst the upturn in risk sentiment and following last week’s Riksbank and Norges Bank policy meetings that keeps them well on track to normalise rates ahead of the ECB.

EM- Broad gains in regional currencies vs the Usd, but with the Mxn a notable underperformer on disappointment that Mexico will not pursue plans to build a new airport. The Brl reacted to Bolsonaro’s resounding 2nd round win by opening higher around a percent vs a flattish close on Friday.

Brazilian Presidential Candidate Bolsonaro has won Brazil’s presidential election according to official results, receiving 56% of the vote in exit polls. Bolsonaro’s top economic advisor has said they will negotiate with more countries, and that the priority is not Mercosur. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent are both down by around 0.3% amid concerns that global growth is slowing, particularly in China, and that ongoing market uncertainties are leading to a downward pressure on prices. Of note with the Iranian sanctions, it is imminent is that India, China and Turkey, three of Iran’s top five customers, are resisting pressure to completely end purchases; citing a lack of worldwide supply for this.

Over in the metals market, gold is down by 0.2% as the yellow metal moves inversely to the USD, although still in a relatively tight USD 5/oz range as market concerns still remain over upcoming US earnings, trade tensions and a slowdown in global economic growth. Elsewhere, the head of the Japanese steel industry group stated that he is worried about the weakening Chinese economy. Copper’s gains have been cut after a slowdown in industrial profits indicate that China’s economy is losing steam, affecting demand for the metal.

Nigerian Oil Minister says OPEC has the ability cover some gaps in 2019; adding that they are overestimating the supply drop. He does not see any dramatic change at the next OPEC meeting on Nov 11th. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Bunds continue to underperform after a brief rebound on the initial Merkel reports, and aside from the drag related to Italian BTPs, which have now been up to 122.63 (+131 ticks), the 10 year German bond is also feeling the weight of a firmer rebound in the Dax and other stock markets with some technical selling also in the mix. Indeed, after breaching a 50% Fib around 160.56 and then 160.50, last Friday’s 160.22 low has also been eclipsed through an interim support area between 160.35-33 to a base of 160.10 (-73 ticks), and bears will now be targeting 160.00.  Meanwhile, Gilts have fallen in sympathy to 122.69 (-40 ticks) and even hitherto resilient US Treasuries are just off fresh overnight session lows and in negative territory, albeit mildly.

Victims of the improvement in risk appetite, with the Franc just off parity-plus lows and Jpy retreating from circa 111.80 to 112.25 amidst similar reversals in cross pairings.

SEK/NOK

Conversely, the Scandi crowns are registering decent gains vs the Eur amidst the upturn in risk sentiment and following last week’s Riksbank and Norges Bank policy meetings that keeps them well on track to normalise rates ahead of the ECB.

EM

Broad gains in regional currencies vs the Usd, but with the Mxn a notable underperformer on disappointment that Mexico will not pursue plans to build a new airport. Looking ahead, it will be interesting to see how the Brl reacts to Bolsonaro’s resounding 2nd round win vs a flattish close on Friday.

content: Bunds continue to underperform after a brief rebound on the initial Merkel reports, and aside from the drag related to Italian BTPs, which have now been up to 122.63 (+131 ticks), the 10 year German bond is also feeling the weight of a firmer rebound in the Dax and other stock markets with some technical selling also in the mix. Indeed, after breaching a 50% Fib around 160.56 and then 160.50, last Friday’s 160.22 low has also been eclipsed through an interim support area between 160.35-33 to a base of 160.14 (-73 ticks), and bears will now be targeting a chart gap down to 160.10 before 160.00.  Meanwhile, Gilts have fallen in sympathy to 122.69 (-40 ticks) and even hitherto resilient US Treasuries are just off fresh overnight session lows and in negative territory, albeit mildly.

subject: JPMorgan says soft growth momentum outside the US is still net-net supportive of USD, even if it appears to be in early-stage normalization
content:
• Says equity market stress has become a fresh source of USD support, "an extension should be USD-positive vs. high beta FX," and says it re-sells NZD vs. USD via an at-expiry digital to hedge against a poor equity market outcome.
  • On the EUR, JPM says that "despite the rapid decline in EUR/USD towards our year target of 1.13, the de-rating of the euro is not exhausted and we recommend awaiting a turn in the data before considering longs."
  • Adds that from a technical perspective, despite the recent EUR/USD sell-off, it still sees the downside limited, but the latest break below key-support at 1.1422 (minor 76.4 %) increased the risk of reaching marginal new lows in the region 1.1277-1.1187

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mixed as the region’s attempts to pick itself up following last week’s stock rout, waned heading into this week’s key earnings releases and month-end. ASX 200 (+1.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) were both initially positive in which the healthcare sector led the broad upside in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark was less decisive as earnings dominated news flow. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.1%) were subdued with the mainland worst hit following softer Industrial Profit growth and a net liquidity drain by the PBoC, while this week’s key earnings including China’s big 4 banks further added to the tentativeness. content:

  • Asian equity markets began the week mixed as the region’s attempts to pick itself up following last week’s stock rout.
  • FX markets were quiet as the DXY held steady near the 96.50 level and with its major counterparts also uneventful.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK mortgage lending, US Core PCE and UK Chancellor Hammond to deliver the Autumn budget statement. Note: UK clocks moved back an hour on Sunday 28th October.

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mixed as the region’s attempts to pick itself up following last week’s stock rout, waned heading into this week’s key earnings releases and month-end. ASX 200 (+1.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) were both initially positive in which the healthcare sector led the broad upside in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark was less decisive as earnings dominated news flow. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.1%) were subdued with the mainland worst hit following softer Industrial Profit growth and a net liquidity drain by the PBoC, while this week’s key earnings including China’s big 4 banks further added to the tentativeness. Finally, 10yr JGBs were choppy as prices reflected the indecisiveness across stocks and eventually edged higher as the risk tone in Japan deteriorated.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 120bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9377 (Prev. 6.9510)

Chinese Industrial Profits (Sep) Y/Y 4.1% (Prev. 9.2%). (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK Chancellor Hammond said UK will require new tax and spending plans, as well as an extension of austerity policies in the event of a no deal Brexit, while he added BoE may also need to act by adjusting interest rates. (Sky News)

German Chancellor Merkel’s governing coalition suffered heavy losses in the Hesse elections with the CDU (27.9% vs. Prev. 38.3%) and SPD (19.9% vs. Prev. 30.7%) each down around 10% compared to the previous election, while the Green party rose to 19.5% from 11.1% and AfD secured 12%. (BBC)

S&P affirmed Italy at BBB; outlook cut to negative from stable and affirmed Germany at AAA; outlook stable. (Newswires)


Fitch affirmed United Kingdom at AA; Outlook Negative, affirmed the Netherlands at AAA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Latvia at A-; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

FX markets were quiet as the DXY held steady near the 96.50 level and with its major counterparts also uneventful as EUR/USD eyes a retest of the 1.1400 handle to the upside, while GBP/USD was lacklustre after last week’s Brexit-related losses in which the pair briefly slipped to below 1.2800. Antipodean marginally extended on Friday’s upside following a rebound in commodity prices and firmer fix by the PBoC, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were slightly choppy amid a similar flimsy risk tone in the region. Elsewhere, LKR and MXN were pressured overnight in which the former weakened to a record low against the greenback on political uncertainty in Sri Lanka, while the Mexican currency was spooked after the country voted to scrap its ongoing new airport project through an unofficial ballot which incoming President AMLO has vowed to make binding and in turn raises concerns regarding honouring long-term contracts.

Brazil conducted the 2nd round of its Presidential Election in which far-right leader Bolsonaro was the official winner. Note: This was as expected considering polls had him ahead prior to the election and as also he had the most votes at the 1st round of the election. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were little changed overnight amid a lack of drivers for the complex and indecisive risk tone, with WTI crude futures holding on to Friday’s recovery but with upside capped by resistance heading into the USD 68/bbl. Elsewhere, gold traded sideways in tandem with an uneventful greenback, while copper traded choppy and  at the whim of the indecisive risk tone.
 

US

US President Trump said on Friday that China wants to make a deal badly but are not ready yet. (Newswires)

US Ways and Means Chair Brady said President Trump’s tax cuts are to wait until 2019. (Roll Call)
